position.marginalia_text: Multùm valet Leo: sed Leo, et Vulpes, multò plus.

marginalia.translation: The lion is very strong: but the lion and the fox are stronger.

position.marginalia_text: Sylla, pla[e]risque foelix; Ceceroni vehemens: vt etiam Ca[e]sar acer. (Nemo admodùm felix, nisi idem vehemens, et acer.)
Omnes res perinde sunt, vt agas, ut eas magni facias. Spiritus intùs alit. Ca[e]sar, iudicio fortis, et inuictus.

marginalia.translation: "All things are just as you may perform them, as you may consider them important." [Glazebrook et al. (eds), 2011, 185]. "The spirit nourishes within." Caesar, brave and invincible in judgement.

position.marginalia_text: Vehementissimi oratores: sic ipse Dauid: sic Vlysses: sic omnes, instructi heroica fortitudine , aut Eloquentia. Diuinus furor, et numen.

marginalia.translation: The most vigorous orators: thus David himself, thus Odesseus. Thus all instructed with heroic valor or eloquence. Divine rage and will.

position.marginalia_text: Camillus furius. Papyrius Cursor. In vno Ca[e]sar, multi Marij. Vim Alexandri, potissimùm a[e]mulabatur Ca[e]sar: Vim Demostenis, Cineas.
Tam in Agendo, quàm in Dicendo, semper acris vehementia excelluit, eet fulmineus vigor: Achilles, Alexander, Ca[e]sar. vehementissimi Actors, Pericles, Demosthenes, Cineas
